Rooms are not as clean as you would expect for a Westin and the hotel is so massive, it feels like a big warehouse. Would not recommend staying unless you need to for business. Inconvenient for all other areas to get to.

Reviews.Title: “good location, but overrated...”
Reviews.Author: Monpetit
Reviews.Content: As participant at a medical congress the Westin Bonaventure was part of the proposed hotel.We choose it because it was possible to walk to the congress center.I've made the reservation the 1st day of the opening site, in June 2007. When we arrive at 8'50 pm, from France, we got the 1457 room, in the middle tower...Nice room, perhaps little in size for three(2 parents and our 14 years old daughter..) but not too little... Problem was the NOIZE...Beware, middle tower is where the vending and ice machine are and they are ANTIQUES... So, I go down and they relocate us to the 1051...in a lateral tower, far from those machines...Rooms here are smaller but as we are not a long time in it(a lot to do...)it was OK...But the tenth floor is the first floor of guest rooms and so you have the "ventilation" fan from the lobby on the "roof" , a little noisy(less than ice machine..). I go down to try to get a room on a higher floor and come the usual sentence : sorry but as you check in late, you've got the last rooms and so in the lower floors...Even with my Starwood card impossible to change...They were sold out... It's not the first time I've this respons in US and I find this policy a litlle...stupid!!! Whe I was student, I've worked in the hotel industry and in France, sooner you reserve and better is the room you have in the category of price you request...Here, just to check in early and you have the best... For the last 2 nights we have had a room adjacent for our daughter, at the same rate, they said...By chance, I verify and on the note, the rate was the one of a triple occupancy...So I've to go to reception to have the correction...(double occupancy for the last 2 nights of the 1051 and single occupancy for the 1052 where was our daughter..). So, nice location in downtown, not far/Stapple center, chinatown, metro...but this hotel has now its "age" and need to be rethinked in size of rooms and room's attribution policy... Erik.

Reviews.Title: “Not the best Westin”
Reviews.Author: RonJon949
Reviews.Content: Not too bad for the low price I got, but this Westin isn't nearly up to the standards of other locations. Carpet and furnishings are due for an upgrade. The hotel in general is a very dated. Not a terrible place, but easy to do better downtown.

Reviews.Title: “Terrible - overrated and overpriced for the experience!”
Reviews.Author: twooSanDiego
Reviews.Content: This was my first and last stay at this hotel … let me paint the picture … as I initially arrive I am impressed with the entrance and the size of the facility and I am expecting a high level of quality. This was not the case. The front desk staff was friendly who checked me in. I went to my room and as I walked in I realized that the room had not been made up! – the bed was messy with hair on the sheets, towels on the floor … not what you would expect at a good hotel. So after a quick call to the front desk, I was assured that I would be immediately moved to a fresh room … (after a long day I’m obviously tired and just want to get settled in) … so after a 35 minute wait in the dirty room someone finally brings me new keys to a different room. The next room has been cleaned and had fresh bedding, but was not sparking clean to the standards you would expect at an upscale hotel …(the remote control had bits of food on it, the side table still had rings where drinks had sat) regardless I was happy to get settled in and get some sleep. However, … as it turns out I’m in a room which has the capability to join to the next room so the sound barrier between these 2 rooms is not as good as it would be in a separate room … shortly into the evening the guests in the next room begin making noise that was very unpleasant and frankly disgusting (screaming and moaning and slapping and more screaming – a bit scary really) I called the front desk to ask to have security stop by …. 25 minutes went by and no security, but the party next door carried on … (on and off for 2.5 hours) … so as the noise continued I called the front desk again and still nothing! This all made for a terrible experience and resulted in my leaving feeling very disgruntled. Service industry? Good luck with the future of this hotel if this type of service continues.

Reviews.Title: “The Hotel Stuck in 1983 - Not in a Good Way, Either!”
Reviews.Author: lointer
Reviews.Content: My husband booked us here for our anniversary in what looked to be an updated Tower Suite with a very nice bathroom. When we checked in, we were upgraded to a Malibu Suite. This is where we realized this hotel was not up to 2007 standards. Our "upgrade" put us in a suite that had thread bare upholstery, stained carpets, old 1980s mosaic tiles with dirty grout. It was gross. We went back downstairs and complained. They changed our room but now we were in a dark little updated suite that faced other rooms. We wondered around the hotel, and found purse shops with faded bags from 1980 (no kidding, price tags and all). We thought we would maybe go to the pool but it had filthy algae floating in it!!!Back in the room, it was utilitarian at best. Bare minimum products in the bathroom. Only one robe. No stationary. No mini bar. We went to dinner at LA PRIME. It was glorified hotel food - I sent the mashed potatoes back because they had become plastic under the heat lamps. The booth we had was threadbare and dirty. All in all, a very working class hotel with no amenities at all. Btw - the Heavenly bed is not heavenly at all - it's hard and uncomfortable!

Reviews.Title: “Good Stay”
Reviews.Author: crashcase
Reviews.Content: Great location.. in the middle of town, starbucks across skybridge. Parking attendants quick and helpful. Rooms are small and could be updated, dbl queen good for 2 people, baths could use an update as well, but are acceptable. I always stay here when doing business in LA, and will continue to do so

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyable”
Reviews.Author: SamNewYorkCity
Reviews.Content: The check in was easy. However, the service for check out was slow. The hotel is very large, but well marked so it is not hard to get around. The rooms are small, but clean. The maid service is adequate. The Gym is small, but there is adequate equiptment. The pool is small and in the shade most of the day. The sun is blocked by the large surrounding buildings. There is no lifeguard. The restaurants are expensive or just fast food. The hotel is centally located. You will need a car to see the city. Parking is expensive at $35 daily. The parking people are pleasant and helpful. The Internet and telephone service are expensive. Overall my experience was adequate and I would stay there again. The prices are reasonable.

Reviews.Title: “Really nice stay - -the staff was superb.”
Reviews.Author: TruNYer
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for a biz trip and overall was very pleased with my stay. The staff was completely amazing, each and every person there could not have been more helpful and friendly. In addition to the usual, the room was full of the amenities I crave -- coffee maker, robe, lots of towels -- and some bonus ones -- disposable razor, toothpaste and more. The one negative I had was with the building structure itself. The building could not be more confusing and difficult to navigate, sometimes downright dopey. Lobby/registration on the lower level, entrance on the 2nd, food on the 4th -- in both cases, one has to walk or take an escalator to the 2nd or 4th floor from the Lobby or 3rd floor (just re-reading this makes my head spin!). The same confusing architecture in the room, I have never seen so many angles, and thus so much wasted space. EVERYTHING was angled, the bed, the bathroom sink, even the toilet! Plus the desk was placed perpendicular to the TV, which made for difficult working time (yes, I like the tv on when I work at a hotel room). And I was also frustrated with how slow it took to get elevators to/from the room. All that said, I still would recommend this hotel. The location was also very convenient for my needs and I was able to walk to MoCA, Little Tokyo and other spots -- and no, didn't get arrested for walking in LA :)

Reviews.Title: “Had a Heavenly Bed & Bath. The rest, not so much.”
Reviews.Author: warthog
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a three night stay at this hotel. On the whole, I found it rather disappointing. The bed, bath, and service of hotel staff all lived up to Westin standards. The rest of the hotel, in my view, did not. I found the room to be dark, cramped, and loud (it was in the Blue tower, facing the elevated roadway outside; you could hear every car and bus crossing over the joints in the road). I had to reject the first room I was offered because of the strong mildew / sweat and faint smoke smell that pervaded it. The second room smelled strongly of something I could not place, but wasn't as offensive so I kept it. Other than the room, I was not pleased with the fact that spa charges and charges at most restaurants on the 4th - 6th floors of the hotel could not be made to the room, and had to be settled via credit card at the time of the transaction. On business, this makes for lots of little bills to add up. (That said, the massage I received at the Spa was tremendous, although the spa facilities / procedures are a bit strange. I don't know the last time I had a spa hand me disposable underwear, for example.) Parking was expensive as others have noted, but the valets did a good job getting the car pulled up and ready with a phone call in advance. I did not use the pool, as getting to the pool area required a walk through the food court and out across the terrace. If there were pool-side changing / bathroom facilities, I did not spot them. I may be forced to stay there again, as the location is too central to my business activities in LA across the street. If it were not for the Heavenly Bed and Heavenly Bath, though, I would not even consider doing that much, and would walk several blocks from a better hotel.

Reviews.Title: “wonderful convention hotel in downtown los angeles”
Reviews.Author: trinity-tiger
Reviews.Content: i attended a very lare conference (3700 people) held at this hotel - the rooms are tip top - the adjoining galleria with shops and restaurants was handy - the food at these restraurants was less expensive than those owned by the hotel - the meeting rooms were wonderful - the main ballroom, the california ballroom, was large enough to accomodate most of the attendees for the main saturday night event - only a few had to go to the overflow area in the santa barbara ballroom - the pool deck was nice i would recommedn this hotel for anyone, especially those who are organizing a convention for more than 2000 people

Reviews.Title: “Great Beds but Noisy!”
Reviews.Author: snorklewoman
Reviews.Content: The Bonaventure was offering a great rate this summer and the "heavenly" bed and the view with the floor to ceiling windows were spectacular. All the hotel staff I came in contact with were very friendly and helpful. Unfortunately, our rooms had virtually no sound-proofing. Not only could we hear the clomping of the people above us, but we heard the intimate conversations of the people next door, including every time they used the bathroom and/or opened the closet door. This practically ruined our stay and I will probably never stay here again because of the noise. Our floor's ice machine never worked, but we did have a little refrigerator. Bathroom toiletries and towels were of the quality you'd expect from this kind of hotel. Sadly, there was no jazuzzi. The hotel is like a mini-village unto itself, with a wide variety of eating and shopping places. However, these aren't affiliated with the hotel. The hotel offered nothing in the way of a map of the place--nothing that stated what was where. The concierge was always busy and I finally gave up. It would have been nice if some maps or something were available explaining the hotel's facilities as well as downtown LA offerings.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel with great staff”
Reviews.Author: Karen_and_Aaron
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Westin Bonaventure for two nights during a brief stay in LA. We booked the hotel through Priceline for $80/night after finding others had received this hotel for that price on BiddingforTravel.com. Check-in was quick and the staff was exceedingly accommodating. I gave them my SPG number at check-in, knowing that it wouldn’t get me points for my stay, but would, as others have noted, get me an upgraded SPG room. Judith moved us from a queen room to a king room on an upper floor and was eager to meet any needs we might have. The lobby is typical John Portman concrete circle madness and was enough to confuse a seasoned plan reader. The staff was very helpful in pointing out the specific elevator bank we needed of the multiple sets on the first floor. Though some described the space as dated, I didn’t find it to be shabby – just dated in it’s styling, in my opinion. Being from Atlanta, I can say that Portman was always ahead of the curve initially, but his designs become outdated very quickly. Our room was clean and simple with a great view of LA. The bathroom was small and strangely shaped, but was adequate for the two of us. The SPG rooms come with a free large bottled water and a refrigerator. On our first night, we went to the 4th floor looking for dining options – none of which were described in any of the literature in the room. We found one tired restaurant after another as we walked the perimeter of the floor. We tried our luck on the 6th floor, without further success and finally decided to go back to the room and order room service. When we got back to our room, I picked up the cordless phone next to the bed to call Room Service, but the phone was dead. After some scrambling around under the bed, we found the phone base to be unplugged. I went back down to the front desk, as they had been so helpful before, to inquire about ordering another way. The front desk staff was helpful and apologetic and insisted on compensating the room service charges, which went a long way to alleviating my frustration. Room service was fine, but not phenomenal. The location is nice – not exactly in the heart of tourist LA, but close to a few downtown attractions and a simple on/off from the CA-110. We ate at Café Pinot one night, which was nice, but not exceptional. Internet access carries a $13/day charge and the valet parking is another $35/night. I would recommend calling down to the valet before you would like your car, as otherwise, the wait can be quite long. Overall, for the price, I was quite happy with my stay and were certainly stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Bonaventure? Tres Bon!”
Reviews.Author: joiseysue
Reviews.Content: I chose this hotel based on price -- w/rental car -- via Orbitz and some online pix. I was a bit leery of the downtown location vs something more happening in, say, SAnta Monica or near the beach. It is an enormous concrete monolith inside. The staff was very very helpful; parking pretty costly at $35.00 per night. Its proximity to the 110 Frwy and the DASH are a very big plus. Since the neighbs is pretty deserted on the weekend, access to nearby routes is impt and made all the difference in our stay. My biggest disappointment is the stores/shops/restaurants within. Many are closed down, others just are dingy looking. The rotating restaurant at top is fun; dessert in the lounge lobby was yummy. And the staff really know their way around or, if they don't, will mapquest areas for you and give you a printout. Very nice.

Reviews.Title: “I would definitely stay here again!”
Reviews.Author: curlyfry
Reviews.Content: The Heavenly beds are in deed "Heavenly". Once my head hit the pillow, I was out till morning. This is very rare for me as I always have a hard time sleeping in hotels. The customer service was excellent. I was always greeted with a smile or Good afternoon. I received room service promptly and the food was superb. The bar near the lobby has a nice atmosphere. They serve great drinks and have an extensive selection. I reccommend the Green Tea Martini. The drinks at the Revolving Bar on the 32nd floor were just as swell. The prices are pretty steep for drinks but then again this is a Westin property. There is also a cool place to go for drinks and nightlife down the street called The Standard. I would stay here again just because of the beds.

Reviews.Title: “2 night stop”
Reviews.Author: LenaWales
Reviews.Content: We have just returned from 15 days travelling on a coach tour of California starting at San Franciso. We had two nights at the Westin Bonaventure and were delighted to hear of Arnie's entrance on horseback from the lifts in True Lies (?) A lovely room with the best beds and pillows of all the hotels used on our stay. One real disappointment was a meal we had in the Italian Restaurant. The food was mediocre and very overpriced. It bared no resemblance to 'Italian' food.

Reviews.Title: “Not a Westin Experience”
Reviews.Author: zuttoman
Reviews.Content: I'm a business traveler and I stay at Westin's all the time. If that statement describes you, you will not like this hotel. "Valet" is really self-park with an attendant that's three stories from the check-in. The rooms are small and retrofitted -- there aren't plugs in convenient locations, the nightstands are in weird locations, and the bathroom is small. I'm an SPG Gold so I was upgraded to a "nice" room. The decor in the lobby and in my room was out of date. The irony is that the Sheraton just down the street gives you a much better "Westin" experience because it's been more recently updated. This hotel is just old and tired.

Reviews.Title: “Reasonable value for a Westin Hotel”
Reviews.Author: johnsmartin4050
Reviews.Content: We found the Westin to be a very busy hotel with a very nice lobby/atrium with plenty of shops, food, and a great bar. The room itself was very small but well equipped. The bathroom looked nice, but again was small. If you bring a vehicle, plan on bringing some extra money for the $35 a night charge as well as giving yourself some extra time to get in and out of their parking garage which is very busy and has only one way in and out which gets very congested. The room was reasonably priced and the service was good.

Reviews.Title: “Japanese Steak Restaurant at Level 6”
Reviews.Author: losangeles08_2007
Reviews.Content: The Hotel is excellent. But please pay attention when you visit the Japanese Steak Restaurant at the 6th level. In any case please ask for a drink menue before you order. A small bottle of Budweiser costs US$ 13.90 for example and a glass or Merlot US$ 13.95. Beside this about 16% of gratuity will be directly added to the receipt. I would recommend to go there only if money does not play a role.

Reviews.Title: “Great Place, but not if you care about your wallet.”
Reviews.Author: gmba
Reviews.Content: The Place and Location itself was excellent. The room was small for 2 queen beds, but yet comfortable, heavenly shower, heavely bed as they had named it did mean all that. Except too pricey for everything else. Room service. TVchannels. Parking was $36+tips a day for Valet. No self park. They say no other parking available as this is in that tall building across from Marriot in the heart of downtown. I found 1 block to its right a self parking for $9.90 for 12 hours at World Trade Center Bldg, (350 S. Figueroa St.) The hotel also accomodates guests mostly from groups and events so do not be surprised to see all kinds of folks of any race, culture or class as the reservation maybe done in bulk at a cheaper rate per room. So the hotel does give out rooms for cheaper than it says on its site. Best bet is to bid the price. Good Luck.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel”
Reviews.Author: RogerVegas
Reviews.Content: This was my third stay with this hotel. The front desk was friendly and we were upgraded to a prefered SPG floor. The room was the same as the previous visit, but the view was better, and free bottled water. The shops and resteraunts on the 3 & 4 floorsI have not dinned in. LA Prime is on the top floor, great place to eat, and the lounge is on the floor below. I will admit the lounge has a dated feel to it, but the view is great, the drink prices aren't too bad for LA and overall it nice starting point. I have eaten at the resteraunt owned by the hotel, Lakeview Bistro I think, for breakfast and it was good. The buffett is the best value, offering fresh juices, coffee, made to order omlettes, waffles, pancakes, yougart, etc. I am not a buffett fan, but this one was good. It was $19.95 per person, the other breakfast selections were $13.95 to $15.95. The only draw back I have, both times, is valet. They are slow. For $35/day I would accept a faster, friendlier service. This time they brought the car up in the lane that guests arrive in and we had to wait another 10 minutes for the car to be moved. Overall it took 30 minutes for us to leave from valet. The rooms are small, bed are perfect, great shower with the double head -- basicly the same Westin room at most Westins just smaller. When I am staying downtown I stay here. Also, not too far from Hollywood -- where we spend most of our time anyway. If you are out that way make sure you stop at the ABBEY for a great drink.

Reviews.Title: “Loved it”
Reviews.Author: flyawayCA
Reviews.Content: I love this hotel and have stayed here on a few different occasions. I mainly stay here for business but I would not hesitate to stay for pleasure. The rooms are very nice and clean. The toiletries are great. They give you magazines to read about what is happening in LA and enough TV channels to suit me. The last time I was there they were recruiting extras for a film, unfortunately I was too busy and heading off to work. I would not recommend leaving the hotel late at night alone if you can help it, it is downtown LA and there are a lot of homeless people. Be careful with the restaurants inside, some are good, others not so much. The staff here are very pleasant and are very willing to change your room for a better view if you just ask. Parking is valet parking only, just tip what you think they deserve. I have never had a problem with them, they were always nice.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent but Beware of Jyokamachi Restaurant”
Reviews.Author: Roscislaw
Reviews.Content: The hotel itself was very nice, with an impressive location, great view from the room, and historically interesting architecture from the modernist movement of the 1970s. The extremely expensive parking was a downside, but it was nothing compared to the horror of eating at the Jyokamachi Restaurant on the hotel premises. This restaurant is not managed by the hotel but is a tenant on the 6th floor gallery/mall above the atrium. The Jyokamachi proprietor was the rudest person we have ever encountered. His attitude was very condescending and racist, the food portions were extremely small and overpriced (we paid $100 for two people and were still extremely hungry afterwards). On top of his awful attitude he quietly slipped himself a 20% tip without telling us (in fact he would not even hand us the itemized receipt to look at, he just asked directly for our credit card), so when we unknowingly added gratuity to the final credit card receipt and a few minutes later went back to him asking him to remove the extra gratuity since we had not been able to check the itemized bill earlier, he got extremely angry and offensive, and called us all kinds of expletives in a foreign language. This was one of the most expensive humiliations we have faced in our lives. This man and his restaurant are a blot on the Westin's reputation and the hotel would do well to get them off the premises. In comparison the owners of the Korean BBQ joint two floors lower offered (in our view) some of the best bargains for good food in the building.

Reviews.Title: “Great value for the price I paid”
Reviews.Author: cdntrekker
Reviews.Content: I transferred to this hotel for a 4 night stay immediately after my stay at Los Angeles Airport Marriott, where I had a fantastic time. It was easy to find with a GPS (my first time driving in LA - having a GPS was a lifesaver!). I really like the building's unique shape and the external glass elevators that shoot up to the 22th floor in a matter of seconds. The lobby is huge and dimly lit. It doesn't help that everything is concrete and glass - makes the space feel cold and unwelcoming. This was reflected in the front desk staff - no smiles, though they were helpful and gave me a nice room in the centre tower (tip: the centre tower tends to have the larger rooms - I saw a king room in the Red tower, and the furniture was older, the room was much smaller). Wireless on the 4th floor worked perfectly. The mini fridge was useful, but the electronic safe was broken. I was later told that half of the safes in the hotel were like that, but in the future they will be updating all of the safes. The bed was amazing after a full day of sightseeing, and the shower was great. Plenty of towels, but why only 1 bathrobe for a room with 2 beds? I didn't like the toiletries provided (very drying - the Marriott's BBW ones were better). The housekeeping service could use some work. On the 3rd day, they woke us up at 8am asking to clean the room. Er, ok that's a bit early, no? The room was adequately cleaned, but items were not replaced daily even with a note + tip. No new tea (although they did replace the Starbucks coffee), no paper or pens, no lids for the coffee cups, fewer towels, no bath mat on the last day, etc. The valet parking staff ranged from surly (the first time I pulled up to the Flower St entrance) to skeevy (when one was trying to be 'overly' friendly with me, yuck!), though the ones inside (next to the front desk) were very nice and helpful, more so than the front desk staff! Tip: if you're parking at night, find street parking or nearby underground parking lot - MUCH cheaper. The location was fine and provided a good base for sightseeing. At night, there are homeless people on the streets, but I never felt unsafe. One morning, we were awoken by protesters shouting in the streets at 6:30am but it was just a minor annoyance. Overall, it was worth the price I paid ($82/night) on Priceline, and I may consider staying here again if I got a cheap rate (I did love the heavenly bed & shower, the floor-to-ceiling windows, and the elevators)... but it is not worth the rack rate IMO.

Reviews.Title: “Not so great!”
Reviews.Author: TravelForFunDeerPark
Reviews.Content: Our stay at LAX Westin was a disappointment. Apparently, some people are happy with their stay at this hotel. I assume that they must have received a different room than we did. I think this hotel has "priceline" rooms, and maybe on rare occasions, Priceline people don't receive these rooms and they are therefore satisfied with their stay. I'll admit the bed is wonderful, and the lobby is grand and makes it feel like a four star, but the four star feeling ends at the elevators. It is a gamble to stay here. If you do decide to go ahead and stay here and you have a problem with your room, insist right away to be moved, because it is unlikely that they will move you otherwise. Buyer beware.

Reviews.Title: “Absolutely loved the Westin!”
Reviews.Author: K9LVR
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a fabulous 4-night stay at the Westin Bonaventure. Were in LA to attend a trade show at the Convention Center, so the location was perfect. Provided busses picked up right out in front of the hotel. Check in was a breeze and our room was ready when we arrived shortly after noon which was a pleasant suprise. Our room, with two double beds, was comfortable and spacious. Plenty big for two women and all their "stuff". We had a great view of the city and the filming of a new Will Smith movie. I personally liked the architecture including the cylidrical shape of the towers and core. Square is boring! The exterior, glass, elevator rides were just plain fun and reminiscent of the Jetsons! We've stayed at the Omni and the Sheraton on previous trips. While both are beautiful hotels, their dining options were limited and quite expensive. My boss (also female) and I both loved being able to just hop in the elevator (which, in itself, was an experience), after walking a trade show for 8 hours each day, and choose from several great dining options. Our favorite was the Bonaventure Brewing Co. Selection was so varied we could eat light or enjoy a full dinner. Must haves are anything entitled "Maytag Blue Cheese" and the Honey Pepper Encrusted Salmon. The garlic mashed potatoes and herbed fries were delicious. The Blackstone Merlot goes well with all dishes. Our waiter, Bryan, took excellent care of us each visit. The small eateries on the 4th floor are perfect for a quick, full breakfast or smoothie as well as night time snacks or dessert at a reasonable price. A breakfast buffet was served on the water feature floor. The hotel is also just a $6.00 cab ride from the Santee Alley shopping area which is a lot of fun. Be sure to indulge in a hot dog with fresh guac and pico de gallo from the many street vendors. We will definately book this hotel next summer when we return for the trade show.

Reviews.Title: “Not even up to Westin standards”
Reviews.Author: elizaba
Reviews.Content: We tend to stay in Westins for little weekend getaways (this one being for our anniversary) so we have come to expect a certain level of quality and this one was definitely below our expectations...it had the usual Westin bed and shower (which we enjoy) but the hotel itself was really in need of renovations...the view from our room was nice but the carpet, wallpaper, upholstery etc. were old and smelly...biggest disappointment was the pool...it being mid-summer in LA my husband and I definitely were looking forward to getting some R&R by the pool but we walked out there in shock...it honestly looked like a pool that should be tucked behind a $39 a night motel in the middle of nowhere...we had to sneak over to the Standard pool...and the 360 Bonavista Lounge at the top had my husband and I chuckling at the 1980's fixtures and "original" seating and fake plants...this all said, the Westin did acknowledge our anniversary with complimentary champagne and chocolate covered strawberries - we just wish we stayed at the Pasadena Westin!

Reviews.Title: “Dark, Mediocre, Unimpressive”
Reviews.Author: KateTravels
Reviews.Content: Having stayed once at the lovely Westin in Stamford, CT, I assumed a stay here would be no different. I was wrong. Booked this room as part of an Orbitz flight/hotel package deal. Obviously was assigned the cheapest room available, which was smaller than a postage stamp and of a strange trapezoid shape. At a shocking seven feet, the ceiling height increased the sense of claustrophobia any guest to this room is likely to have. (Above the bed a section was hollowed out of the ceiling, presumably so that anyone standing on the bed would not knock their head due to the low clearance). On the positive side, the room offered spotless bedding and a surgically clean shower. But the carpeting was old and just felt dirty to walk on. This hotel participates in the "Wayport" internet access racket, whereby you get to pay a hefty $12.95 per day for wireless or DSL access in your room. (This rate is per computer, not per room.) Other hotels in LA provide complimentary internet access (The Belamar in Manhattan Beach), so why can't the Westin? Instead it seems they are into nickel-and-diming their customers. As I was there on this visit to search for housing, and could not reasonably live without the Internet for the duration of my stay, this expense irritated me. To add insult to injury, Wayport does not offer a volume discount for several days of access. File under: DUMB. While the hotel offers an amenity they call the "business center," be prepared to pay $7.50 for--I'm not kidding, folks--two minutes of internet access, and two pages of printouts. (I asked if I had to pay for a single staple for my materials; the staple was free, much to my amazement.) The final kick in the genitals came in the form of a ridiculous $35/day mandatory valet charge. (BTW--call ahead of time or be prepared to wait for your car.) $140 for four nights of storing a car in a garage. Money well spent! Aesthetics-wise, the hotel is dark and cave-like. The lobby smells of chlorine from all the tacky bubbling pools and on the whole feels severely dated. It's 2007 and 70s retro concrete chic is no longer chic. The carpeting throughout (esp near the valet area in the sub-basement) reeks of despair. It's a horrible entry point for arriving guests! Dark, bad lighting, ugh! All in all, if you have to be in downtown LA--sure, go for it. This place is centrally located right off the 101 and you could do worse. But I would opt for something else in the future. This hotel felt more like a budget Marriott than a true Westin.

Reviews.Title: “Pretty disappointing”
Reviews.Author: rkagarwal
Reviews.Content: We booked the Westin Bonaventure for two nights on our 10-day California road trip. We used Air Canada Aeroplan miles and were pretty excited to be staying at a Westin cost-free. Unfortunately, the stay was pretty disappointing. Though the bed, linens and shower were excellent quality, the rooms, hotel property and service were dated and below expectations. In addition to a small room with a small tube TV (and a non-working remote control), the carpets were stained and the guest directory had not been refreshed. We were on the 23rd floor facing east into another tower. The property itself was gargantuan but pretty ugly. The eateries on the 4th floor looked like a dirty food court, complete with plastic trays and dirty tables. That being said, I went down to the Lobby Court looking for some bagels or croissants for breakfast (i.e. Starbucks-type food unavailable at the "Starbucks" in the lobby) and the hostess let me grab a few bites from the buffet without cost. The valet parking was a disaster. In addition to costing $35 per night, they routinely parked our car off-site, meaning that we had to wait 20-30 minutes after trekking to the garage for our vehicle. The front desk service was poor. Our folio showed a balance of $300 notwithstanding that we had provided our Aeroplan certificates at check-in. I called the front desk and was promised a return telephone call, which never came. Eventually, I trekked down and had the issue resolved but wasted 30-40 minutes correcting the hotel's error. The Bonaventure Club spa is not a Westin spa. Though the massage I had was very good, the spa was weirdly appointed. It was a cross between a golf club and a Roman spa. Very strange. The concierge did give me a $10 gift certificate when I called down looking for a spa menu. Our room rate was $156, which is probably not bad for downtown L.A. That being said, I'm unlikely to stay at the Bonaventure again.

Reviews.Title: “Ok for the money we paid”
Reviews.Author: max3743
Reviews.Content: Booked hotel on Price Line. Parking is $35 per day. After the first day we park at the World Trade Centre next door these a bridge link to it only $9.90 per day as long as you park less than 12 hours. Not a good base if you are in holiday we spent most of our 7 days driving to beach areas. If you are looking at this hotel for a holiday do not book it cheep for a reason. Pay the extra and staff near a beach. Hope my comment help

Reviews.Title: “Met my expectations... That's all”
Reviews.Author: Montyaloofah
Reviews.Content: I had just stayed at the Four Seasons in San Francisco before checking into the Westin Bonaventure. Bit of a downer after staying in lux conditions. Arriving at the Westin was a little painful. The valet parking in underground and the signage was very poor. After cirlcling the block 2 times, finally made it down. You have to take a series of elevators to get to the lobby from the garage level. Check-in was very smooth. They offered warm cookies and pink lemonade to all new guests. The lobby area was a bit of an oasys with vegetation and water all around. The center bar area looked like a nice spot to grab a drink. The 2 levels above the lobby were shopping areas which give it a mall type feel... I got a room on the 30th floor of the yellow tower with an east facing view. the view was excellent. The room left something to be desired esp after the FS stay. The bathroom was small. The fixtures were dated and bathtub slightly discolored. there were some stray hairs on the bathrrom floor when I first walked in... I'm not too disgusted by this but others may be. The room itself was very small, just enough room for the bed, TV, and a small table. The lighting fixtures were almost dangling and in need of repair. The carpet was stained in areas. The best part of the room was the bed, which was indeed Heavenly. The sheets were also very nice. Beware, there is a ledge behind your head on the bed. If you're not careful, you can bang the back of your head on it's edge... There was options for both wireless and wired internet in the room. That was very convenient. The things that annoyed me most about the Westin was not being able to contact Valet to retrieve my car. At $35/day, pick up the phone!!! I never got through to them so had to go down and go through the motions. I had to wait ~30min because they couldn't find the car... The gym facility was nice and open 24hours. Not like I'm gonna work out at 2am, but good to know it's open. All in all, the hotel was just ok. It was what I expected. best of all, it was 2 blocks from my meeting. I would only stay here again given similar circumstances. Privacy Alert: The cylindrical nature of the towers means that some rooms face others. I had the nice treat of catching 2 lovebirds in their morning mating ritual in another tower. It went well with my coffee and muffin. If you don't want to give anyone else a show, close your shades....

Reviews.Title: “Awful Customer Service - Billing issues”
Reviews.Author: We_Go_Everywhere
Reviews.Content: I am the travel coordinator for a large, global company. I have a good understanding of hotels all over the world, the different chains and what level of services they offer. I booked my employees at The Westin Bonaventure thinking that Westins are usually pretty decent across the board... I've since changed my mind on that. After making my online reservations, I requested a credit card authorization for be faxed to me to cover the room charges in advance, as not to inconvenience my travelers. After numerous calls to the Westin Bonaventure with no response, I emailed the Starwood corporate customer service to request this basic, generic form. It took 10 business days for corporate to even respond. I was shocked that their answer was for me to tell them which hotel I was referring to (which was stated in my email) and that they'd be glad to give me the hotel's phone number.?. Talk about a useless response and a waste of my time. I called the hotel again directly and got an accounting person who finally faxed me the form. I emailed to advise that this form was to cover multiple rooms for multiple guests and was assured that they'd notate each account... this (of course) didn't happen and they made my attendees use their personal credit cards to secure the rooms, saying there was no credit card authorization on file??? Come to find out- they got the form, and put it in one of my employees file and that was it. So the rest of my employees' rooms were left "unpaid" despite the Westin already having the payment. I had two employees call me in a panic because the front desk / reservations people weren't allowing my employees to check in (on their arrival date) or check out (on their departure date) saying the rooms hadn't been paid for. It was a fiasco from start to finish. Booking hotel accommodations isn't brain surgery. A hotel's employees should be able to follow it's own policies and procedures without me having to constantly be in contact with them from across the country. Bottom line- I got nothing but hollow excuses and absolutely no service what so ever from corporate. I will not be recommending the Westin Bonaventure to anyone and I certainly will not be booking any Westin rooms for my employees or anyone we do business with.

Reviews.Title: “the beds R 2 die 4”
Reviews.Author: michelleaziz
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I stayed there last summer for a quick escape to the heart of los angeles. The rooms are really mod with the most comfortable beds/pillows Iv'e ever laid on...u literally sink in @ least a foot into the bed when u get on! We had an incredible view of the city ( from a standard room) and the style of the hotel was very chic. Just when I thought I was getting a steal for an " L.A." based hotel I realized I had left my car in the hotels lot that charges you $10.00 dollars an hour . I ended up spending $85.00 dollars on just parking fees!!! There are other areas around the hotel to park with meters that will cost you 10 times less, so look around. All in all it was a good exp.

Reviews.Title: “In the very heart of L.A.”
Reviews.Author: MichaelInSF
Reviews.Content: We did a weekend stay at the Westin Bonaventure in downtown Los Angeles. The hotel is right in the heart of downtown Los Angeles which, as other reviewers have pointed out, can be remarkably devoid of life after business hours and on the weekends. The architecture is indeed very unique, and as I'm from Detroit originally it feels a little bit bizarre to spend nights in a hotel that seems to be a quarter to half size clone of the downtown Detroit's Renaissance Center. It'll probably take a new visitor a day to get accustomed to how things are laid out. On the reception level, there's a cafe on the main floor, as well as a bar hugging the center core of the building. The 3rd floor has a pretty complete gym and they've turned the area around the center core into a running track, complete with exercise equipment in overhanging pods. I'm sure the architect would be spinning in his grave if he saw this, but it's nice payback to what he's forcing hotel guests to go through. The fourth floor has nifty shops and restaurants which make nice alternatives to the expensive hotel restaurants, but the fourth floor is inaccessible from the guest room elevators. You'll need to take an escalator or go up one of the spiral staircases to get up there. Our package came with a choice of breakfast buffet or room service. We opted for the buffet both mornings we were there. They had made-to-order omelets, scrambled eggs, different kinds of hot meats, plates of cold cuts, little boxes of cereal, cut up fruit, bread and pastries. Our "upgraded" "Starwood Preferred Guest" room was pretty small, but I was very thankful that the air con/heater unit had a nice loud fan, which helps me to sleep. Along with a complimentary bottle of water, there was also a fridge in our room (other reviews point out that SPG rooms have the fridge), where I was able to store some of the perishables we bought on the 4th floor's "French Market" (they sell cheeses, bottles of wine and soft drinks, and other assorted foods and collectable knickknacks). The bathroom and bedding in our room was all "Heavenly" brand... the famous double headed shower, comfy bed, etc. That part was really nice.

Reviews.Title: “Needs some TLC”
Reviews.Author: havanahipster
Reviews.Content: I stayed in the Malibu suite (3177/3178). I had floor to ceiling windows with a great view. But the rooms leave a little bit to be desired--worn carpets, stained countertops, black dust on the air vents, and the list goes on. If you were inside the room and asked what hotel chain this is you would probably say Crowne Plaza or Clarion, not Westin. The hotel location is good if you need to be centrally located within downtown LA or if you need a short drive to Universal or Hollywood Bowl. This hotel runs quite a few price promotions during the week, so you should be able to score a rate of $129 like I did. Check travelzoo.com for promotions or try all the promotions and AAA rates on westin.com. Any rate over $129 is simply not worth it for this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “good rooms, but nothing to do in the neighborhood”
Reviews.Author: Triptaker365
Reviews.Content: Our room was on a high floor with a reasonable view of downtown. We liked the unique architectural features of the hotel. The room was small but everything in it was fine. No complaints. The concierge was extremely helpful in describing outside activities. There is not much to do at the hotel. We tried to walk around to get a flavor for the neighborhood, but the hotel is close to nothing. Just lots of roads, cement walls, tall empty buildings (on weekends) and nothing much going on. So I suppose this is a good place to stay if your primary goal is business, not tourism.

Reviews.Title: “A period piece..”
Reviews.Author: ShepRoss
Reviews.Content: This hotel was a showplace in the late 1970's early 1980's. I think "JR" when I sit at it's revolving lounge and watch the city go by. It's the largest hotel in Los Angeles and feels a bit Jetson-esque with it's multi leval terraces and weird stairways and elevators. I rarely get lost in hotels, but I've done it several times here. It's integrated by bridges into the city and for those who know the way, it's a bit of an adventure navigating the vertical terrain of Bunker Hill. The rooms are comfortable with elegant bathrooms and interesting vierws of the city. ( Notice I didn't say beautiful. )Priceline rates are a great bargain. The pool on the 4th floor allows you to swim among the skyscrapers. Unfortunately you have to hike through hallways in your swimming attire to get there. Restaraunts in the area are great, ie Nick & Stefs, Tesoro, Cafe Pinot and Water Grill and it's easy walking distance to the growing downtown nightlife. For a fun and educational weekend contact the LA Conservancy and book a Saturday morning walking tour of the history of downtown.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location Courteous Staff”
Reviews.Author: goodboye7641
Reviews.Content: My wife and I returned about 2 weeks ago from LA visiting friends and family. The location was great for sightseeing. We did not have to go out late to look for inexpensive restaurants. There was a variety of places to eat within the hotel (Chinese, Italian, Subs & steaks). McDonalds and other inexpensive eating places were just across the street. The staff was superb. From the concierge desk, the bell men, Derrick (at the Flower Street entrance), Rosario (maintenance employee in the lobby restroom. They all went out of their way to make certain that we were pleased and felt welcomed. Darrell behind the desk broke a $100 dollar bill for at the last minute 6:00a.m. in the morning for us to leave a tip in our room. The Dash bus stop was right in front of the hotel (.25cents) per ride. We were able to visit the fashion district 3 times with that convenience. We felt safe since certain doors were locked at specific hours and elevators were restricted to going down and not up at a certain time (unless a room card key was used). This was my second time staying in the Bonaventure. The only thing that we could complain about are the thin walls. We could hear conversations and T.V.s on one side. I think it was because we were in a little corner. We had a great front view, so we did not want to give that up for a little noise. S. Boye (So. Maryland)

Reviews.Title: “A total dump!”
Reviews.Author: crazyfirehydrants
Reviews.Content: This hotel is a total dump. I booked a stay at this hotel on Priceline in early June for three nights, I stayed one. If you are familiar with Westin hotels and think this place would be along the same lines you would be terribly mistaken. The Westin Bonaventure is at BEST a two star hotel. The rooms reminded me of a Comfort Inn I stayed at when I was a kid... in the early 80's....in Flagstaff, Az. The problems.... The rooms are horribly out of date, think 'A Clockwork Orange'... No really..... Orange striped wallpaper... The bathroom was disgusting, dirty, again out of date, and had a standup shower only, with a shower head that came to my chest. The common areas are again, dirty, worn, and just plain uncomfortable. There are a great many more nice hotels in the area, including a new Omni around the corner that I would recommend. LA is too great a city to have a trip ruined by this place...

Reviews.Title: “Unacceptable”
Reviews.Author: crosscountry63
Reviews.Content: I booked my reservation through hotwire and got what I thought was a great deal. I arrived at midnight, having already paid for the room, but there were no clean rooms available. There was a line of people ahead of me also waiting for a clean room. I finally got a room at 1:30 a.m. after almost falling asleep in the lobby. The desk clerk offered to comp my breakfast and parking, which I accepted. The amount of the comp turned out not to cover the cost of the breakfast, and I just got my bank statement to find that I was charged the full amount of the parking - $35 - as well as an additional charge for some undetermined service. I don't even know how to go about getting the charges reversed, and I'm sure it wouldn't be worth the headache. The room was ok, but given the poor service I received, I would never stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “A town within the city.”
Reviews.Author: Matt N
Reviews.Content: I was in LA for a conference at the Westin and thoroughly enjoyed my room and the service at the hotel. The rooms are a bit odd shaped because the towers they occupy are round, but I had plenty of space, a nice desk to work at, and a wonderfully appointed room. The marble bathroom was very nice and very clean. There is free WiFi in the brew pub, or if you don't want to have to order a drink, you can just sit on the same floor and get a signal.

Reviews.Title: “Wierd lobby layout, tired rooms”
Reviews.Author: go_leir
Reviews.Content: I wasn't impressed with this hotel. The lobby is strangely laid out: almost handicapped inacessible, steps everywhere. Confusing, noisy, main floor - you have to go through the restaurant or up and down steps to get to the elevators (and it's down one floor from the street). Above (floors 2-6 or so), the elevators only stop every 2nd floor and those are NOT the floors that stores, restaurants are on - need to walk up or down a flight of stairs that are hard to find. Rooms are small and feel tired, furniture is dull, bathrooms have low quality fittings - no style or interest to this hotel. Huge and impersonal but without the luxury sometimes associated with Westin. Nothing obviously wrong with it (clean, service OK) but not somewhere I'd really want to stay again. Location is OK in downtown LA - about a mile from the convention center.

Reviews.Title: “No Disapointments @ The Bonaventure”
Reviews.Author: Zzamm
Reviews.Content: Short & sweet -- stayed at the Bonaventure from Friday May 18th to Tuesday 22nd of May & completely enjoyed the whole experience.. Parking was $35 nightly; costly but all lots in downtown LA are. Front Desk was XLNT; it certainly helps if you're SPG. Was upgraded to 30th floor & had a few nice perks addedd in the room. Service was fine without any of the often-seen bad attitiude about a Priceline booking @ $55. Common Spaces are really interesting, diverse & probably enough to satisfy most all people. So many different restaurants, exercise facilities & diversions. Elevators were fun & fast. Room was small, but in very, very fine condition. The bed, the view, the bathroom & the double-headed shower were fine! Housekeeping was XLNT. Will definately stay there again!

Reviews.Title: “Big, convenient downtown LA hotel”
Reviews.Author: PdxJulie
Reviews.Content: The Westin Bonaventure is a huge hotel in downtown LA. I stayed there on business and it was convenient for me. Downtown LA is absolutely a wasteland after 6 pm - there is no one on the streets and it's pretty creepy. The Westin has several dining options in the hotel, which is nice. The hotel is all nonsmoking and the beds are comfortable. The room was entirely adequate, but nothing special. The fitness center is not that great, as the glass walls open to the public areas of the hotel, so guests walking through the hotel can see you in there sweating away. The treadmills were nice though, with individual video screens.

Reviews.Title: “A true LA landmark”
Reviews.Author: robertocusato
Reviews.Content: I stayed at Westin Bonaventure during 3 nights in early October 2006. I first opted for the Millennium Biltmore, but then - given the attractive low fares - I decided to opt for the Westin. I don't know how was the Biltmore, but the Westin Bonaventure was a solid 4* hotel indeed. The outside is grand! You can't miss the 4 cylinders making up the hotel, they are truly spectacular! If you drive a car, the best option is use the hotel's valet parking. It's a bit steep in price - 25 USD per night - but it's worth it, definitely. Check-in staff at the front desk is welcoming, always smiling and accommodating. Checking-in was easy as 1,2,3 and we got our room overlooking from the 13th floor the AT&T building. The room was clean, even if furniture was a bit tired and old. The bed was very comfortable, the room was spacious, and so was the bathroom. No shower stall but only bath tub, even though it was very large. The heavenly shower is very pleasant, you should try it. Amenities were provided, as well as hairdrier and double basin and bathrobes. The view was spectacular, overlooking LA's downtown skycrapers! The hotel lobby was big. Well, strange was the first thought which came to my mind, as it was pure, plain cement. It's incredible the number of restaurants present in the hotel! You can have a bit of everything: chinese, japanese, korean, american pizza... WOW! The lobby bar was nice, with many monitor broadcasting sport (college football was at its peak). We had breakfast at the bar one morning, and even if pricey it was delicious (try their eggs benedict, please!) The hotel hosts also a restaurant at the top floor, a steakhouse, famous for its steaks and its view, but it's pricey and a formal/smart-casual dressing code is required. So we avoided it. The gym club is very nice, on the first level of the hotel, and it's Adidas sponsored! Take a look at the jogging loop, wow, never seen something like this anywhere else! The Westin has also a pool, outdoor, but it's small and to be honest not so clean (sunbeds are availables too). I liked this hotel, and so did my girlfriend. If you're in town for business, probably it's an unmatched spot in downtown LA. But since doentown hasn't that much to offer to tourists, I guess next time I will chose such places as Santa Monica or Beverly Hills to base myself, and this is the advice I give to other tourists as well. I rate this hotel a solid B++!

Reviews.Title: “Bonaventure Is The Best”
Reviews.Author: HuskyFanNY
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Bonaventure with a friend of mine last year during our trip to LA. I can honestly say that this was the best hotel I have ever stayed at. I paid $199 a night for the five nights I was there and can honeslty say I think I got a bargain. First and foremost, the rooms were clean and well attended to. The staff was as friendly and helpful as the day is long and the makeup of the structure, with so many floors, shops and restaurants insured that you could never be lacking. The only slight critique I have is more me than the hotel itself. This is such a massive building with unique architecture that it can be hard to navigate when you first get there, but after a day, you'll be a pro. I would defintely recommend it to a friend and can't wait to stay there again on my trip to So Cal this summer. Matt, New York.

Reviews.Title: “Overall good hotel”
Reviews.Author: Edistotiger
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for a week while attending a business conference taking place in the hotel. The staff overall was very friendly and helpful. I was only put off one time by one concierge, who wasn't of any help when I asked for recommendations for local restaurants (he only named those in the hotel; when I inquired as to some outside the hotel, he merely shrugged). The rooms are a little small but very adequate in size. I had a wonderful view of downtown LA and the mountains in the background. The hotel does have a 70s - 80s feel in decor (as a former resident of Atlanta, it was easy for me to pick out the various signs of a Portman designed hotel) but that did not matter to me at all. SPG rooms have a refrigerator (my colleague, who is not an SPG member, did not have one in his room). The room was clean; maid service was excellent during my stay. The bathroom was nice. There are several food court type restaurants in the hotel, but I did not try any of them. We ate one time in LA Prime; prices were high but comparable to those found in similar restaurants in other large cities. My colleague said that his steak was excellent (I was too cheap to spend that kind of money on a steak that I knew was too big for me to finish; I had the grilled vegetable platter, which was good). The food at Bonaventure Brewery was good also. I did not have an opportunity to use the exercise facilities but they looked good; I never saw lines of people waiting for equipment whenever I walked by. The Staples Center and Disney Music Hall are nearby. public transit is only a short walk away. The hotel staff provided excellent support services for our conference. I had a very pleasant stay overall.

Reviews.Title: “Welcome to the 70s--and that's not a bad thing!”
Reviews.Author: ezzy4751
Reviews.Content: A John Portman masterpiece--if you're an architecture buff. Hotel is made of 5 funky glass silos with glass elevators that run on the outside of the building. Huge atrium with lots of water features of course. It's a big hotel so a bit impersonal but the staff was extremely friendly. Everyone I ran into, even in the elevators, was very curteous. Wifi in the rooms had very weak signal but I'm not surprised considering the concrete structure and the round buildings. If you arrive late, be sure to have taxi take you to Flower Street entrance, not Figeuroa, which is closed after a certain hour. I was dropped off after 11 p.m. and couldn't get into the hotel. They should install a phone at those doors so guests can call the front desk. Fortunately, an exiting guest let me in. Overall, a very nice hotel with very comfortable beds. Maybe a little pricey but probably the average for downtown L.A.

Reviews.Title: “nice food court!”
Reviews.Author: NJvacation
Reviews.Content: My familiy of four (2 small children) stayed here during a recent conference at the LA convention center. we had two adjoining rooms, which was very spacious for the children. Very nice staff and clean rooms. Comfortable beds. The pool was very nice. However, the real draw is the food court right in the hotel! This was great as it allowed us to have simple meals for us and the children.

Reviews.Title: “Great Room and Amenities Plus Fantastic Location”
Reviews.Author: travelcommons
Reviews.Content: This hotel is located perfectly in downtown Los Angeles and the price we paid via Priceline came to about $115 per night with all taxes and fees. The standard room was fine with the Heavenly Bed, Starbucks in-room coffee maker, double shower head and nice toiletries. There's a nice selection of cable channels and one premium (Showtime, I think), and big picture windows give the room plenty of light. The small fridge was another bonus. The hotel itself reminds me of a cruise ship. Huge lobby with restaurant and bar, water fountain features, lots of restaurants and business services including car rental, and just across the street is Koo-Koo Roo Chicken, Starbucks, La Salsa and Quiznos (closed when we were there). It is about a 10 minute walk to the Metro 7th Street Station, where you can catch the subway/lightrail to Hollywood and other locales without a car. Or walk one block and catch the DASH buses, which only cost 25 cents and run every 5-10 minutes on 5 or 6 fixed routes. The Visitor Center is also located very close by, and the library is 5 minutes by foot and you can use free Internet for 15 minutes without having to register or anything. Walk up the steps (or if you are really tired, take the escalator) of Bunker Hill, and then find the guideposts for a walking tour of the area. We enjoyed the hotel because of its location and comfort. We didn't use any business services, but I did see the business center and it seemed useable. The room service menu or breakfast delivery is a bit expensive. Each morning there is a breakfast buffet for something like $25. Save some money and go across the street to the Undeground Mall and you can find a McDonalds and 4 other little quick service restaurants that can get you a great morning breakfast for under $8 a person including coffee. I've seen people get this hotel on Priceline for $75 per night (depending on the date), which would make this property very unbeatable for what you get. Even at $115 per night I give this place a 5.

Reviews.Title: “Too Big!”
Reviews.Author: fourstar
Reviews.Content: After waiting hours to get a room previously booked but they had no record of it? . Finally got a room late evening. The room a bit small, but with fantastic veiws over the city. Most of the food is a "fast food" type on floor 4 and 6. suggest you ask the bell captain for a map of the local restaurants. I can recommend Mc Cormicks & Schmicks sea food restaurant one block away. Large menu and wine list at reasonable prices. Large queue for breakfast, even at the breakfast bar.

Reviews.Title: “Good hotel, great location”
Reviews.Author: djjackyl
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed here for a night on April 8th for the Lakers game and enjoyed our stay. Staples Center was 8 blocks away a good 20 minute walk. The hotel's interior is huge and a bit overwhelming but we were able to find our way around. The rooms were a bit on the small side but the floor to ceiling windows make up for the lack of size. We had drinks at the revolving lounge at the top of the hotel which is a must if you stay here. Overall we had a great stay and would recommend this hotel to anyone staying in the downtown area.

Reviews.Title: “Overpriced and extremely disapointed”
Reviews.Author: maitai326
Reviews.Content: I regret booking this place. But not that i could help it, it was booked for us through hotwire.com. Dont let the 4 star hotel line trick you here. 1. more like 2.5 or 3 star hotel 2. holiday inns have been better 3. rooms were small, anyview of the city was obstructed 4. shower head in the bathroom were almost falling out from the walls. 5. lobbys, hallways and elevators were from the 20 -30 years ago. 6. service at the concierge was terrible. offered no help or suggestion. was not knowelgeable at all, even to resturants IN the hotel 7. parking was $25 a day!!!!! ended up to be not so much of a bargain after all 8. pictures on thier homesite was mislead, not anything close to the reality! 9 3 words: DONT GO HERE. there are SOOOO many other places in downtown LA...

Reviews.Title: “Very pleased”
Reviews.Author: CHerPig
Reviews.Content: We (4 adults) used Bonaventure as our base for 3 days of independent touring. We appreciated the safety of this all-encompassing hotel and its' very convenient access to Hollywood, Beverly HIlls, and Little Tokyo (GREAT authentic Asian restaurants!) We toured via rental car each day and used a nearby public parking garage for overnight parking @ $15/day. The public parking is cheapest UNLESS you will be needing in/out privileges throughout the day. (In which case you are charged $15 EACH time you exit the garage!) Our experience with the front desk and concierge was very good. We booked 2 rooms through Priceline, paying slightly over $100 plus tax for our Friday and Saturday night stays. Rooms were average in size with a VERY comfortable bed and we LOVED the double-head shower. It is true that there are MANY lunch-spots within the Bonventure towers. In addition, there are a couple of overpriced dinner restaurants, We strongly recommend using car or taxi for better dinner choices.

Reviews.Title: “A disappointing stay at the Bonaventure Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Linda-Frank
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Bonaventure Hotel several years ago and were "wowed" by it, but nowadays, it's pretty tired looking. It could really use some spiffing up. The room was quite pricey, was on the small side, but clean, and the bed was comfortable. The view of downtown L.A. from the huge windows in our room was spectacular. The lobby area was beautiful and had lots of shops and restaurants. The one negative is that the customer service was terrible! We needed assistance with travel to the Staples Center to see the Los Angeles Laker's game and got little help and alot of attitude! Usually the concierge in a large hotel is very helpful, but after calling them twice and also talking to them in person, we were quite disappointed. The front desk staff did seem nice and professional, however. The parking situation was a nightmare, very expensive, and the parking atttendants in valet parking were real jerks. Should we go back to L.A., we'll not be staying there again.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel was nice Pricey parking”
Reviews.Author: traveler475
Reviews.Content: Booked the stay on Hotwire. Comfortable Bed, Nice Room. Only complaint is the $35 per car/per night charge for self and valet parking.

Reviews.Title: “Westin Good...Parking & Internet Service Bad”
Reviews.Author: wdharrington
Reviews.Content: This is the second or third time I've stayed at this hotel. Checkin was extremely fast and easy. The rooms are small, but the beds are great, although some of the furniture is starting to show its age and wear. The showers are terrific, but the bathroom can really only accomodate one person. If you plan on using their internet for $12.95 please understand its speed is close to that of a 56K dialup service, it is a BIG incovenience if you're trying to conduct business in a timely manner. This hotel has plenty of places to eat, but really only for lunch and most of them are pretty average. The layout for the hotel is easy to navigate and they were filming a movie the weekend I was there. My biggest beef with this property is the $35 a day to park and they only have valet, so you are doling out more cash for tips. Note to the hotel: having the option to self park would be much appreciated.

Reviews.Title: “Great Service, Rooms Small”
Reviews.Author: SkiCountry
Reviews.Content: The Service was excellent from the time Super Shuttle picked me up at the Airport, to check-in, to the bellman (James), to Billy the Concierge, room service, banquets, bartenders, the doorman, and even Richard Suh with Suh Young M Limo & Tour Service, were all A+. I was so busy with business that I did not get to enjoy much of the hotel, my room was smaller than what I'm used to but I don't think there is much that can be done about that due to the Portman design of the building, very much like the Westin Peachtree Plaza in Atlanta. I have a Sprint Wireless Card which worked great in the room so I did not have to pay for internet there as they do charge. The Banquet I experienced was excellent and the staff were very attentive. The elevators seemed to have some problems but nothing major, just would stop once in awhile making you wonder if you were going to get stuck. Overall experience was good and the service is what really sticks out in my mind, I was wondering who was going to stop the A+ streak but no one did, they were all great.

Reviews.Title: “Friendly hotel for being large, not close to anything”
Reviews.Author: ShutterGo
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for a conference, so had limited choices to be near the convention center-- and even that was 12 blocks away. For what I saw of downtown LA, this was the best choice for hotels, but downtown LA is not really getting an LA experience if you don't have to be there for business or a conference. There are few restaurants nearby and nothing interesting to see. The hotel itself was fine. The staff was very friendly and helpful, especially unusual for a large chain. The parking was ridiculously priced at $35 per night and no other options nearby. The eating options were limited with only a fair food court or more expensive hotel dining available. The pool was outside and advertised as heated, but there was a cold snap (temperature 50 degrees) and the pool unswimmable. The exercise facilities were above average but fairly public (could view people exercising from the elevator). The room itself was the best-- very comfortable bed, nice desk chair, and a wonderful view. The room had a real mini-refrigerator (not a mini-bar) that helped with the limited restaurant access.

Reviews.Title: “Great Value with Urban 80s Appeal”
Reviews.Author: GenX_PHX
Reviews.Content: Above all, this is one of the best hotel values in LA. For the same price I paid here, my other choices would have been much less appealing. This is no five-star hotel, though, and even giving it four might be a stretch. The location dowtown is convenient to freeways and pretty central if you need access to several parts of the city. But you should absolutely know that parking is valet-only in an underground garage, and the hotel charges guests $35 a night to park here. When you enter, the lobby is impressive in a "Secret of My Success " (80s Michael J. Fox movie) sort of way. As you ride up the elevators to your room in one of several towers, you go past several levels of defunct mall-style shopping and restaurants. It's actually quite creepy. Anyway, the elevator ride is cool with views of the city, and then you arrive on your floor. Here, the rooms are arranged in circular towers. The rooms are very small, but typical city hotel room size. Decor is dated, but the room was clean and pleasant. I had a room on the 28th floor, and the view was spectacular. It really made the room. Signature Westin Heavenly bed is here, but I was disappointed. It seemed really firm, and I didn't sleep well. Bathroom was clean and re-furbished, and nothing was too scary about the room or bath. My biggest complaint is that for such a large hotel, it really lacks any good fast and healthy food options on-site. I did realize on my last day, though, that there is a walkway that connects the hotel to a little strip mall with a Jamba Juice, Starbucks, Chipotle and some other choices that are waaaaaay better than the choices you'll find inside. I ended up with some so-so coffee in a plain styrofoam cup and a Costco muffin in a zip-loc bag two mornings because it was the best thing I could find on-site. So if you're looking for a decent place to stay for under $150, this place beats most of your other options in that price range. I wouldn't recommend it as a special occasion hotel, but it's a great place if you're on a budget but don't like budget hotels.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent and Great Value for Money”
Reviews.Author: BritTraveller68
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for a long weekend vacation in LA, having stayed here a few years ago, when at a conference down the street at the LA Conference Centre. Prompt and friendly service at check-in. Stayed in the central "column" of the hotel, adjoining the "red" tower. Could hear one of the hotel's trademark outside evalators from within the bathroom, but not in the bedroom fortunately. Enjoyed my stay then and thoroughly enjoyed my return visit. Judging by the carpets, the place has been refurbished recently. Bedroom was large in my opinion, with plenty of space around the king-size bed. The famous "Heavenly Bed" was just that. Temperatures rose outside while I was there, so I had cause to use the air con. This was very quiet...the quietest I've ever experienced in a hotel...so kept the room chilled at night, but without disturbing my sleep. Bathroom was a good size too and the double-headed shower was a bonus. Clever idea that delivered a great shower experience. I was on an SPG floor, so not sure if the wide range of bathroom products is normal. Impressed to find not only a toothbrush but a small tube of Colgate toothpaste and a small canister of shaving foam. If I had one negative comment to make, it would be that the bathroom could have benefitted from one more light above the sink, but that's a personal perference matter. Minibar was really only an empty fridge, in which I put my SPG complementary bottle of water. Used the wireless internet connection which cost €13 per day. The system did suffer from some reliability problems. Every now and again, the connection would be lost altogether, but would either correct itself within seconds or, if it didn't, I was able to "repair" the connection quickly from my laptop without any problems. It was only a minor inconvenience...."niggling" more than annoying. I ate breakfast in the atrium poolside restaurant. Wide choice, piping hot food and beverages and a chef on duty to prepare eggs and omlettes. The $20 buffet was good value, when compared to ordering off the a la carte menu. Friendly wait staff too, although the one on the first day did slip in a pre-filled out feedback form with my bill, that needless-to-say gave her a glowing rating. I would have marked her highly anyway, but it was still a bit cheeky. I also had a meal one evening in the lobby bar area. Not a wide choice from the bar menu, but good value and very tasty. Hotel is on the edge of the downtown area. I wanted to be close to the opera house and it was just a 10/15 minute walk (uphill). Superb fish restaurant (McCormick and Schmick's) around the corner, at the top of a staircase feature (Bunker Hill Steps) on 5th Street. Considering I had only paid $159 per night, via the SPG.com website, when neighbouring hotels wanted between $209 and $249, this hotel offers a great value for money experience.

Reviews.Title: “Fine Stay at the Bonaventure”
Reviews.Author: kiwitravelerpdx
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Westin Bonaventure for three nights in conjunction with a huge conference (1500+ attendees) and booked my room directly with the hotel using a conference reservation code. I'm also a Starwood Preferred Guest Gold member. The conference rate was $130/night and because of my elite SPG status I was upgraded to a "tower suite" in the Green tower. The two rooms and 1-1/2 baths were probably created from two original individual rooms, which by themselves would have been quite small. The room was very nice with Westin's "modern" furnishings and, of course, the Heavenly Bed, which is truly fabulous. I had two televisions--one each in the bedroom and living room. Everything was clean and well-maintained. Broadband internet in the room was via wireless or direct Ethernet connection. The Bonaventure is a product of John Portman, who loved atriums, fountains and pools in the lobby, and it's very 1970's. Lots of concrete contribute to a rather sterile feel--sort of like the outside brought inside. The Westin, of course, really can't do much about the dated design short of destroying the building. The arrangement of separate towers clustered around a central core makes for a rather confusing layout. You're OK once you've figured out the color-coding and which floors don't have elevator service. If you want a more "intimate" or "classic" feel to your hotel experience, don't stay at the Bonaventure. Dining options either in the hotel or downtown area are either very cheap or expensive. The Bonaventure has LA Prime Steakhouse which is as pricey as any national chain steakhouse (Morton's, Ruth Chris, etc.). A "food court" has several fast food venues (Chinese, Korean, pizza, etc) at which you can get something for $5.00. The Bonaventure Brewing Company is available for "moderate" prices. I didn't try it, so I can't comment on quality or value. Just around the corner and within steps of the Westin is Cafe Pinot, one of Joachim Splichal's restaurants. Wonderful "cutting edge" cuisine with entree prices in the upper $20's. My partner and I went there and it was truly worth every dollar! The fitness center at the Bonaventure is great! Contrary to a few previous reviews, I thought the equipment was very up to date and well maintained. Cardiotheater is available at every station. Access is available anytime with a room key, and there is no charge! There's also an indoor track with a special running surface that encircles the central tower on the same floor as the fitness center. You would feel like a hampster after going around the short circuit more than a few times. The lighted heated outdoor pool may be just short of twenty feet in length and is quite adequate for lap swimming. This is also available anytime. The water is clean and clear. Parking is expensive at $35/day (tax included in this amount). But, for being in downtown LA surrounded by skyscrapers, I didn't expect much better. Overall, a very nice stay!

Reviews.Title: “Treated like 2nd Class”
Reviews.Author: Auditor_Mom
Reviews.Content: A very wise teacher once told me that people will often forget names and places, but they will never forget how you made them feel. That sums up my experience at the Bonaventure - made to feel 2nd rate and like I didn't matter. I stayed here only because it was my conference hotel. Room seemed ok, but when I awoke the next morning, I noticed a significant water drip from my bathroom ceiling. Not knowing what type of water may have been leaking from the floor above (toilet??), I went to the hotel desk. After suggesting that maintenance could probably easily fix it, they finally agreed to give me another room. Apparently housekeeping wasn't told I moved rooms, because after returning from my conference in the evening, my room had not been cleaned at all. Another trip to the desk resulted in aoplogies and "Sorry, but housekeeping has gone home for the day, what can we do to make it right?" the desk clerk asked. I mentioned that most of my fellow conference goers had received some nice chocolates in their rooms the previous night, and something of that sort would go a long way in making me feel better about the dirty room. Promises, promises . . . I returned after the night out to find nothing in my room. The hotel desk was again very apologetic, but by that time I felt nothing less that 2nd rate. Upon check-out, the clerk had the audacity to suggest I give the hotel another chance! Why in the world would I do that?!! The bed was comfortable, but I was so mad that I never did get a good night's sleep. Save your money, find a hotel property that puts customer service first (as I have always experienced with Hilton hotels).

Reviews.Title: “Expensive Overnight Parking”
Reviews.Author: Russkar
Reviews.Content: The Hotel is nice and Service is very good. The GUEST OVERNIGHT PARKING just increased today from $25- to 35- per night which for LA seems Excessive? I'm going to re-think staying here in the future?

Reviews.Title: “Heavenly heavenly heavenly”
Reviews.Author: pinecohen
